Description: To settle charges of fixing prices of shelf-stable tuna fish from as early as the first quarter of 2011 through at least as late as the fourth quarter of 2013 Bumble Bee agreed to pay a $25 million criminal fine, which would increase to a maximum criminal fine of $81.5 million, payable by a related entity, in the event of a sale of Bumble Bee subject to certain terms and conditions.

Bumble Bee Foods, Tri-Union Seafoods (which markets Chicken of the Sea) and StarKist agreed to pay $3.3 million to District Attorneys in Marin, Riverside and San Diego counties to resolve allegations that they failed to meet federal standards relating to the amount of fish in their cans of tuna. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Bumble Bee Foods agreed to pay $6 million in replacing equipment, restitution, fines, penalties, court costs and environmental fund donations, in settlement of charges it failed to implement and maintain safety programs, resulting in a worker being killed inside an industrial tuna oven when it was turned on. The settlement came with a guilty plea to the misdemeanor.

Info Source: Contained in a spreadsheet obtained from the agency on October 7, 2020 in response to an open records request. The spreadsheet contains cases from the enforcement database accessible at https://enfo.gaepd.org/Orders/Search
